awd_titl_txt: Quantum and Nonlinear Photonics in Silicon Carbide
awd_abstract_narration:
The project is jointly funded by the Electronic and Photonic Materials (EPM) and the Condensed Matter Physics (CMP) Programs, both in the Division of Materials Research (DMR), and by the Electronics, Photonics, and Magnetic Devices (EPMD) Program in the Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems (ECCS).

Non-technical Description: This project develops a new platform for strong interaction between light and matter - using an optical cavity (resonator) nanofabricated in silicon carbide that simultaneously contains optical emitters (color centers) and localizes light in an overlapping, sub-wavelength volume. Such a platform enables switching one optical beam with another and changing its color - even with very weak beams, at the level of only a few photons. The potential applications of these effects include building blocks for secure quantum communication systems over long distances, optical equivalents of electronic switches operating at much lower powers and higher speeds, and magnetic field sensors. This work therefore combines photonic engineering, with materials/nanoscience, and fundamental physics. The project contains educational and outreach activities integrated with research, including active recruitment of minorities and women for science and engineering careers, development of new classes and textbooks, undergraduate research and advising, and participation in outreach programs for K-12 students and teachers.

Technical Description: The focus of this research is the development of a quantum and nonlinear photonics platform based on silicon carbide nanophotonic cavities with embedded ensembles of optically-active crystalline impurities (color centers). Ensembles of suitable quantum emitters are generated (e.g., via electron beam irradiation) inside nanofabricated photonic crystal cavities with high quality factors and small mode volumes. Such a platform is probed in a variety of custom-built optical setups to study nonlinear and quantum optics, and multi-emitter cavity quantum electrodynamics effects at room temperature and at low optical power levels. The observed effects are employed to build optical switches at the level of a few photons (for optical communications and computing), to interface long-lived states of quantum emitters in silicon carbide to photons propagating in fiber optic networks (with applications to quantum networks), to build on-chip light sources for wavelengths from visible through mid-infrared, and to sense weak magnetic fields.

por.por_cntn:
Quantum and nonlinear photonics are important research fields that study strong light and matter interaction and have applications in telecommunications, quantum information processing, generation of novel light sources, and nano-scale sensing. The silicon carbide (SiC) substrate has a unique set of properties for achieving new photonics capabilities, as well as for uniting functionalities seen in several traditional quantum optical materials into one platform. The result of our three-year NSF DMR program is that cubic (3C) and hexagonal (4H) polytypes of silicon carbide are now developed to the level of substrates suitable for implementation in a wide range of fundamental studies and scalable photonics applications. Moreover, this project has supported the development of several emerging experts, including two female physicists; helped grow the larger SiC research community through international collaborations and conference presentations; and provided science outreach to over 10,000 K-12 students in the Bay Area.

 

The main technical contributions of the project are the nanofabrication processes, modeled photonic devices, demonstrations of scalable photonic systems, and the development of a novel multi-emitter cavity quantum electrodynamics (QED) framework. We have developed three nanofabrication processes utilizing HBr/Cl2 and SF6 plasma for generating features as small as 200 nm in free-standing structures in 3C-SiC and bulk-supported structures in 4H-SiC. We have also demonstrated the proof-of-principle undercutting of bulk 4H-SiC through three directions: Faraday cage-assisted angled etching, focused ion beam angled etching, and the quasi-isotropic etching. Using the Finite Difference Time Domain modeling, we have designed photonic crystal and microdisk resonators that confine high quality factor resonances at visible and infrared wavelengths suitable for cavity QED and nonlinear optics processes, as well as nanopillars that can efficiently guide color center light into an optical interface. The developed fabrication processes allowed us to demonstrate the telecom wavelength photonic crystal resonators in 3C-SiC, the visible wavelength microresonators coupling to the intrinsic luminescence in 3C-SiC, Purcell enhancement of color center emission in hybrid diamond-SiC microresonators, a scalable array of color center single photon sources and spin-qubits in 4H-SiC operating at room temperatures. Finally, our theoretical efforts to develop multi-emitter cavity QED framework have yielded in a prediction of a new mechanism for generation of non-classical light and an application of the scattering matrix theory to nanophotonics resulting in a capability to model unprecedentedly complex color center-cavity systems.

 

The results of our research were disseminated through peer-reviewed publications, conference presentations, and Vuckovic group’s website and Instagram account. This project has supported a recently graduated female PhD student who was subsequently awarded a prestigious postdoctoral fellowship at Stanford University. This project also contributed to a training of another female graduate student who has recently won a competitive OSA conference award. Together with the PI, these students have been active in science outreach and conference organizing, taking leadership positions within the Stanford Optical Society. These efforts affected over 10,000 K-12 students and over 300 photonics professionals in the Bay Area.
